Posts.Content: Mar 18, 2011 05:54PM dannade wrote: hollyinMich:  I had lymph node dissection after my original mastectomy because the sentinel lymph node in frozen dissection in the hospital showed negative.  So two days after I was home, the doctor called to say I had a positive node and would need lymph node dissection.  He then took out 21 more nodes in my left arm and had to sacrifice the large nerve.  I came home and it was painful and hard to stretch and I felt like spiders were crawling up and down my upper arm.  Then, I had the burning sensation under my arm (which I still have sometimes).  The worse was as you  mention, the chafing feeling, like your skin is raw from rubbing against rough material.  The spider feeling went away after about 2 weeks, the raw skin feeling went away in less than 2 months.  I did not get lymphadema, however I went to a lymphadema specialist to prevent it and she has worked wonders with all the weird feelings in that arm.  My original surgery was Oct. 2009.  I had immediate reconstruction with implants - left side failed and had to be removed 2 weeks later, a few weeks after this was the lymph node dissection, then radiation, no chemo - my choice.  I just had reconstruction on the left breast 3-1/2 months ago and it's not going all that well.  But my PS will take care of me.  I have another surgery on that breast next month.   The numbness remains under the arm and under the upper arm.  Radiation was also a culprit. I was put on gabapentin for joint pain and hot flashes.  It did the trick, but was very constipating so I stopped taking it.  The oncologist changed me from Arimidex (post menopausal) to Tamoxifen which does not affect the bones and I'm doing well on it.

Posts.Content: Mar 30, 2011 08:27AM dannade wrote: I think all the recovery depends on age, fitness and body structure.  I am 65, had this done 4 months ago and have had various challenges.  Tummy is still swollen and I have a little bit of a bulge when I pull myself forward - we are watching this.  Going April 27 to have a fat necrosis removed, some adjusting and the dogears near the hip area where the scars end fixed and some hip handlebar fat removed (my PS just said  he'd do this, don't know if it's really part of the phase II).  I was not a super physically active person, 30 lbs. overweight and not so young anymore.  Although, I have a very active life.  I now walk everyday and try to do crunches to strengthen my tummy.  I went in for DIEP, but I am almost sure it was a free flap because PS took a cuff of muscle with the vessel.  He insists he does it this way to protect the vessel.

Posts.Content: Mar 19, 2011 06:34PM dannade wrote: charmaine;  I had bmx Oct. 2009 with immediate implants.  frozen SN dissection came back negative.  But pathology showed SN to be malignant.  While planning to have the lymph node dissection, my left implant area filled up with fluid and I had to have the implant removed.  Then I had the lymph node dissection.  A couple months later I had radiation on the same side.  Immediately after the lymph node dissection, I felt like I had spiders crawling up my upper arm, I had burning in my armpit, which I still do sometimes, and the numbness under the arm and the upper arm that is closest to my back.  I was told the numbness under the arm would not go away due to the doctor cutting the nerve to get to the lymph nodes.  And it hasn't.  I did go immediately to a lymphedema physical therapist to prevent lymphedema and help with scarring.  It has meant a world of difference.  I have to watch what I pick up and  just this week I lifted a few more items than I should have and the heavy feeling in my arm is back and the burning underarm.  Most everything goes away, but physical therapy is the way to go.  Some numbness just stays.

Posts.Content: Mar 18, 2011 09:07PM dannade wrote: randi64 - I have lymph node dissection because I had one node positive in my original BMX on the left side.  I should not have agreed to it, out of 23 nodes taken out, the sentinel node was the only positive node.  What a cruel way to diagnose something.  This was in Nov. 2009 and I am still seeing pt mainly because of so much scar tissue build up.  I did not get lymphedema, but it could come along any time if I am not careful.  I did have radiation because of that one lymph node and because my skin margins were not enough (I think that was something the surgeon should have had more control over).  However, I did not have chemo.  I had two tumors in the left breast, the one with the positive node and surprisingly one tumor on the right side, diagnosed 2 weeks apart, Left side were ductal and right side was lobular.  I only had radiation on the left side even though the radiation oncologist wanted to do both (I am so grateful I did not have both sides done).  I had two Oncotype DX tests on the two left side tumors which were the two worrisome sites.  Both came back in the low range and convinced me amidst many tears of indecision that I would not have chemo.  I am on Tamoxifen now even though I'm post menopausal because the Arimidex hurt my joints and hot flashes were unbearable.  Tam works differently and my bones feel better and the hot flashes seem to getting milder.  Yes, I believe we should weigh all things before we go with 'standard of care'.  And, I have a chemo oncologist for a good friend - he was not too happy with me.  But, I did what I felt was right for me.  And I live each day as fully as possible.  Good luck with all your decisions.
